image.altText: Two people sitting across from each other in dark room

items.synopsis: Thousands of South Australians are being denied the basic mental health support they need because of a lack of services and funding at a grassroots level, an independent review into delivery and funding finds.

title.children: Mental health support shortfall leaves 19,000 South Australians in the lurch

image.altText: Pilot sitting in the cockpit of a small plane.

items.synopsis: Former US Marine pilot Daniel Duggan speaks publicly for the first time from his prison cell as he fights extradition to the United States over allegations he trained Chinese military pilots more than a decade ago.

title.children: Australian 'Top Gun' pilot speaks publicly for first time since his arrest for allegedly training Chinese military pilots

image.altText: A composite of a woman with long blonde hair, and a young person holding an Adidas sneaker.

items.synopsis: When Byron Bay woman Sarah Luke found out her personal details had been shared on the dark web, she never imagined it would lead to two US court actions and a million-dollar damages bill.

title.children: Data breach victim told to pay Adidas, National Basketball Association $US1.2m by US courts

image.altText: A drone shot of Lake Menindee glowing orange at sunset.

items.synopsis: Water Minister Tanya Plibersek says the $13 billion Murray-Darling Basin Plan deadline must be extended.

title.children: Basin Plan targets won't be met on time, says water minister

image.altText: woman looking into the camera

items.synopsis: A Supreme Court jury has been told a woman found dead in a creek near Newcastle had told her father she had a $25,000 bounty on her head.

title.children: Jury told dead woman believed she had bounty on her head

image.altText: A woman celebrates scoring a goal

items.synopsis: It's day six of the Women's World Cup, featuring co-hosts New Zealand and Norway, who knocked the Matildas out of the last World Cup. Follow live.

title.children: Teen star scores for Colombia in opening World Cup win, while Korean 16yo breaks record

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Colombia hangs on to its 2-0 half-time lead and opens their Women's World Cup account with a win for the first time. The match at the Sydney Football Stadium was the final tournament opener, with Korea, ranked 17th, no doubt disappointed to go down the 25th-ranked South Americans. South Korea was pretty thoroughly outplayed in that one, barely threatening aside from a couple of chances at the end of each half. Meanwhile, Colombia's goals came from a penalty for handball and a goalkeeper blunder, so they will have to improve their execution if they're to match it with a high-flying German side on Sunday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Colombia wraps up first round of group games with a 2-0 win over South Korea

props.alt: Colombia players smile while South Korean players talk in the foreground at the Women's World Cup.

children.content: (ABC News: Brendan Esposito)
Colombia hangs on to its 2-0 half-time lead and opens their Women's World Cup account with a win for the first time.
The match at the Sydney Football Stadium was the final tournament opener, with Korea, ranked 17th, no doubt disappointed to go down the 25th-ranked South Americans.
South Korea was pretty thoroughly outplayed in that one, barely threatening aside from a couple of chances at the end of each half.
Meanwhile, Colombia's goals came from a penalty for handball and a goalkeeper blunder, so they will have to improve their execution if they're to match it with
a high-flying German side
on Sunday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Casey Phair enters the fray for South Korea as a substitute for Choe Yuri in the 78th minute and becomes the youngest player at a men's or Women's World Cup at just 16 years and 26 days old. She's also the first multi-racial player to turn out for the South Korean national team, men's or women's. She's just, and I have to say just, eclipsed Ifeanyi Chiejine, who played for Nigeria 34 days after her 16th birthday at the 1999 World Cup.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A new youngest-ever World Cup player

children.content: Casey Phair enters the fray for South Korea as a substitute for Choe Yuri in the 78th minute and becomes the youngest player at a men's or Women's World Cup at just 16 years and 26 days old.

props.alt: Casey Phair walks on the field in a white South Korea kit at the Women's World Cup

children.content: The Korean-American has played for South Korea's junior teams but this his her first game at senior level.
(Getty)
She's also the first multi-racial player to turn out for the South Korean national team, men's or women's.
She's just, and I have to say just, eclipsed Ifeanyi Chiejine, who played for Nigeria 34 days after her 16th birthday at the 1999 World Cup.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Catalina Usme kicked things off from the spot before a strike from teen sensation Linda Caceido made it 2-0 for the South Americans. The crowd at the Sydney Football Stadium is going off, with the a distinct fluoro yellow tinge in the stands.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: HALF-TIME: Colombia 2-0 South Korea

props.alt: A Colombian fans holds up a lion's head in the stands at Women's World Cup.

Catalina Usme kicked things off from the spot before a strike from teen sensation Linda Caceido made it 2-0 for the South Americans.
The crowd at the Sydney Football Stadium is going off, with the a distinct fluoro yellow tinge in the stands.

image.altText: A woman wearing a blue shirt and gloves kneels in the dirt next to a bucket as she reaches into a hole with a small tool

image.altText: Julian Sands wearing open-neck blue shirt and purple jacket staring into camera.

items.synopsis: Authorities rule the British actor's cause of death as "undetermined" after his body was discovered by hikers in California.

image.altText: A composite image of Veena Sahajwalla on the left, Craig Reucassel in the middle and Nina Gbor on the right

items.synopsis: Ahead of tonight's premiere of War On Waste, host Craig Reucassel, eco stylist Nina Gbor and scientist Veena Sahajwalla are on deck to answer your recycling questions, bust myths, and provide the inspiration to take action.

title.children: From commercial to household rubbish — how can we fight the war on waste? Join our live Q&A

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Any idea when plastic takeaway containers and plastic fruit and vege wrapping will be banned? Good to hear single use plastic is on its way out. The consumer can only do so much. - Barbara. Thanks for your question Barbara but unfortunately the answer is probably not what you're hoping for. Here's Craig 's advice: Barbara I hate to disappoint but I can't see a ban like this happening anytime soon. In some cases plastic can be useful in food transport and storage as it extends the life of the food. I'm not saying I like this system, just saying there is little genuine talk of changing it. The problem with banning it entirely is finding alternatives. Cardboard and paper (which has a higher recycling rate) can be used in some cases, but not in all cases, for instance where packaging needs to be water proof. Indeed, trying to make cardboards and sugarcane pulps water proof can have potential problems (see ep 2 for more). Bioplastics are sometimes suggested as an alternative but they currently make up only about 1 per cent of the market and they have their own environmental challenges. If we could make reliable and cheaper bioplastics from waste products then that may help, but that doesn't happen at scale yet. If you can grow food at home or buy it locally direct from farmers then that's your best bet for avoiding the plastics for now.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: When will plastic takeaway containers and food wrapping be banned?

children.content: Any idea when plastic takeaway containers and plastic fruit and vege wrapping will be banned? Good to hear single use plastic is on its way out. The consumer can only do so much.
- Barbara
Thanks for your question Barbara but unfortunately the answer is probably not what you're hoping for.
Here's
Craig
's advice:
Barbara I hate to disappoint

but I can't see a ban like this happening anytime soon. In some cases plastic can be useful in food transport and storage as it extends the life of the food. I'm not saying I like this system, just saying there is little genuine talk of changing it. The problem with banning it entirely is finding alternatives.

Cardboard and paper (which has a higher recycling rate) can be used in some cases, but not in all cases, for instance where packaging needs to be water proof. Indeed, trying to make cardboards and sugarcane pulps water proof

can have potential problems (see ep 2 for more). Bioplastics are sometimes suggested as an alternative but they currently make up only about 1 per cent of the market and they have their own environmental challenges. If we could make reliable and cheaper bioplastics from waste products then that may help, but that doesn't happen at scale yet.
If you can grow food at home or buy it locally direct from farmers then that's your best bet for avoiding the plastics for now.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Karen: My understanding is that sending textiles (no good for reuse or rags) to textile recycling businesses is currently the best path in Australia. Do you agree? Sandra: So, I'm trying to sort assorted old clothes and other fabric items into our house into fabric types to re-use. Problem is, there's a lot of synthetics that I'm not at all interested in keeping around long term. While I can do my best to avoid acquiring more in the future, I feel kind of stuck with the polyesters etc. that I already have. Is there any functional large scale fabric recycling system on the horizon? (Hoping not to have to send it to landfill.) L:Absolutely I will donate/sell clothes and usable fabrics, but how about once the clothes teach end-of-life (aka rips apart and can no longer be repaired)? Is there a sustainable way to ensure they get made into rags in Australia, or is it better to send to landfill What to do about recycling our clothes is definitely something a few people are keen to know more about. Here's Nina Gbor 's take on the current situation: Hi Karen, Sandra and L, there isn't a single large textile recycling system in Australia yet, but there a few recyling companies operating. I think we need to advocate for the government to provide a system so that Australians can stop sending over 200,000kg of textile waste to landfill each year. It's NEVER a good idea to send clothes to landfill. Textile recycling facilities should be the last resort if possible. Do an online search for one(s) that you can take your worn out clothes to. The truth is that we need a comprehensive textile recycling facility here in Australia. This is something we can advocate for the government to provide.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Are there any large scale fabric recycling systems on the horizon?

children.content: Karen: My understanding is that sending textiles (no good for reuse or rags) to textile recycling businesses is currently the best path in Australia. Do you agree?

Sandra: So, I'm trying to sort assorted old clothes and other fabric items into our house into fabric types to re-use. Problem is, there's a lot of synthetics that I'm not at all interested in keeping around long term. While I can do my best to avoid acquiring more in the future, I feel kind of stuck with the polyesters etc. that I already have. Is there any functional large scale fabric recycling system on the horizon? (Hoping not to have to send it to landfill.)

L:Absolutely I will donate/sell clothes and usable fabrics, but how about once the clothes teach end-of-life (aka rips apart and can no longer be repaired)? Is there a sustainable way to ensure they get made into rags in Australia, or is it better to send to landfill
What to do about recycling our clothes is definitely something a few people are keen to know more about.
Here's
Nina Gbor
's take on the current situation:

Hi Karen, Sandra and L, there isn't a single large textile recycling system in Australia yet, but there a few recyling companies operating. I think we need to advocate for the government to provide a system so that Australians can stop sending over 200,000kg of textile waste to landfill each year.

It's NEVER a good idea to send clothes to landfill. Textile recycling facilities should be the last resort if possible. Do an online search for one(s) that you can take your worn out clothes to. The truth is that we need a comprehensive textile recycling facility here in Australia. This is something we can advocate for the government
to provide.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ok I'll fess up one of the recycling questions I was dying to ask was whether you need to remove all the sticky tape from a cardboard box before you pop it in the recycling bin. Craig has come through with the goods: As the person who used to stand by the recycling bin picking off all the plastic I have good news for you (and me). You can leave the sticky tape on. It will be removed in the recycling process. YAY!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Does sticky tape need to come off before you recycle a cardboard box?

children.content: Ok I'll fess up one of the recycling questions I was dying to ask was whether you need to remove all the sticky tape from a cardboard box before you pop it in the recycling bin.
Craig
has come through with the goods:
As the person who used to stand by the recycling bin picking off all the plastic I have good news for you (and me). You can leave the sticky tape on. It will be removed in the recycling process.
YAY!

image.altText: Stocks displayed on a screen at the ASX

items.synopsis: Investors are bracing for Australia's inflation data, US tech earnings and global central bank meetings. ASIC launches court action against Vanguard. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX on the rise, ASIC takes Vanguard to court alleging greenwashing

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While China has announced a number of stimulus measures to boost its slowing economy, investors are looking for a bigger sugar hit. Yesterday China's top decision making body, the Politburo, said it would "step up economic policy adjustments" to expand domestic demand and lift confidence. "Currently China's economy is facing new difficulties and challenges, which mainly arise from insufficient domestic demand, difficulties in the operation of some enterprises, risks and hidden dangers in key areas, as well as a grim and complex external environment," Xinhua quoted the Politburo as saying at a meeting chaired by Chinese President Xi Jinping. China's economy slowed down from April to June because of weaker demand at home and aboard, although it did expand by 6.3 per cent over the year to June, a step up from the year to March. Economists at Barclays say while the Politburo meeting signalled more support for the economy, it fell short of offering large scale stimulus. "We view this as a signal that the government would stabilise growth around its target but refrain from an outsized policy response, given the top leaders' intended shift in focus to "quality growth." Barclay's Yingke Zhou, Ying Zhang, and Jian Chang are predicting more targeted stimulus instead of the big spending packages of the past. They expect further interest rate cuts, more special bond issuance by local governments, and other measures including lending by policy banks to support infrastructure investment, especially green infrastructure investment. "We think the PBOC (People's Bank of China) has already entered a rate cutting cycle, and expect a 10 basis point (0.1 percentage point) cut every quarter through the first quarter of 2024 to reduce financing costs in the economy, along with 40 to 60 basis points of mortgage rate cuts for both existing and new housing loans." They also expect the central bank to further lower funding costs for financial institutions. The Politburo also called for measures to encourage spending on big ticket items including cars, electronic products and furniture, as well as promoting spending on services like sports and leisure. China's Commerce Ministry has already announced a plan to boost consumption of household goods, which includes a directive to local governments to increase the renovation of old homes. China's economic planning agency, the National Development and Reform Commission, has also outlined measures to promote private investment.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Barclays expects more targeted Chinese stimulus

children.content: While China has announced a number of stimulus measures to boost its slowing economy, investors are looking for a bigger sugar hit.
Yesterday China's top decision making body, the Politburo, said it would "step up economic policy adjustments" to expand domestic demand and lift confidence.

"Currently China's economy is facing new difficulties and challenges, which mainly arise from insufficient domestic demand, difficulties in the operation of some enterprises, risks and hidden dangers in key areas, as well as a grim and complex external environment," Xinhua quoted the
Politburo as saying at a meeting chaired by Chinese President Xi Jinping.
China's economy slowed down from April to June because of weaker demand at home and aboard, although it did expand by 6.3 per cent over the year to June, a step up from the year to March.
Economists at Barclays say while the Politburo meeting signalled more support for the economy, it fell short of offering large scale stimulus.

"We view this as a signal that the government would stabilise growth around its target but refrain from an outsized policy response, given the top leaders' intended shift in focus to "quality growth."
Barclay's Yingke Zhou, Ying Zhang, and Jian Chang are predicting more targeted stimulus instead of the big spending packages of the past.

They expect further interest rate cuts, more special bond issuance by local governments, and other measures including lending by policy banks to support infrastructure investment, especially green infrastructure investment.

"We think the PBOC (People's Bank of China) has already entered a rate cutting cycle, and expect a 10 basis point (0.1 percentage point) cut every quarter through the first quarter of 2024 to reduce financing costs in the economy, along with 40 to 60 basis points of mortgage rate cuts for both existing and new housing loans."
They also expect the central bank to further lower funding costs for financial institutions.
The Politburo also called for measures to encourage spending on big ticket items including cars, electronic products and furniture, as well as promoting spending on services like sports and leisure.
China's Commerce Ministry has already announced a plan to boost consumption of household goods, which includes a directive to local governments to increase the renovation of old homes.
China's economic planning agency, the National Development and Reform Commission, has also outlined measures to promote private investment.

props.alt: Graph showing interest rate cuts in China

children.content: China interest rates
(Wind, Barclays Research)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's a cold winter in many parts of Australia and the cost of heating your home has surged after electricity price increases this month. Research by consumer finance website Finder shows that South Australians are being worst hit by the increase in power prices with an annual estimated rise of more than $800. Here's the breakdown: South Australia: estimated price rise of 22% to 63%. A more than $800 annual increase for some customers. New South Wales: bills went up by 15% to 36%. An increase of up to $420 a year. Victoria: power prices rose by 22% to 31% with an annual price increase of up to $396. Queensland: estimated price increases of 8% to 41% with an annual price rise of $548. Saving money Finder surveyed 1,090 people and found 79% are planning to cut back on their energy usage over winter to save money. 56% plan to switch off lights and power points when not in use 54% plan to reduce use of heaters and air conditioners 21% switch to energy saving lightbulbs 9% will work from the office instead of home 9% switch electricity or gas providers Finder recommends you chose the right heater for your home and says reverse-cycle air conditioners are the cheapest to run. It also recommends that you compare and switch energy plans and look for rebates and concessions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Power bills jump by more than $800 a year

children.content: It's a cold winter in many parts of Australia and the cost of heating your home has surged after electricity price increases this month.
Research by consumer finance website Finder shows that South Australians are being worst hit by the increase in power prices with an annual estimated rise of more than $800.
Here's the breakdown:
South Australia:
estimated price rise of 22% to 63%.
A more than $800 annual increase for some customers.
New South Wales:
bills went up by 15% to 36%.
An increase of up to $420 a year.
Victoria:
power prices rose by 22% to 31% with an annual price increase of up to $396.
Queensland:
estimated price increases of 8% to 41% with an annual price rise of $548.
Saving money
Finder surveyed 1,090 people and found 79% are planning to cut back on their energy usage over winter to save money.
56% plan to switch off lights and power points when not in use
54% plan to reduce use of heaters and air conditioners
21% switch to energy saving lightbulbs
9% will work from the office instead of home
9% switch electricity or gas providers
Finder recommends you chose the right heater for your home and says reverse-cycle air conditioners are the cheapest to run.
It also recommends that you compare and switch energy plans and look for rebates and concessions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A few hours into trade and the local share market is still up by around 0.3 per cent, so a fairly modest gain. That's despite a really standout session for the miners, more than recouping some of the losses they posted yesterday — shares in Fortescue are up 5 per cent, Rio 's up 4.1 per cent and BHP has gained 3.8 per cent. Energy stocks are on the up, with Santos gaining 1.1 per cent so far. Despite the good performances, the gains across the broader index are being capped by falls in the financials sector — shares in Westpac have dropped 1.4 per cent. And most other sectors are posting losses as well. 119 of the top 200 stocks are in the red as it stands.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX hanging onto modest gain, Fortescue up 5%

image.altText: Natalie Keley wears a blue shirt at Go Between Bridge, where her sister Teisha Keley was found dead

items.synopsis: Many would have passed by the tangled mess of tents, swags and junk that made up a homeless camp along a riverside walkway in Brisbane's CBD, but no-one realised they were walking past a dead body.

title.children: Tragedy under a city bridge: How a homeless woman was neglected in death as she was in life

image.altText: A serviceman with a Russian flag on his uniform stands guard near the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant wearing a face covering

items.synopsis: The International Atomic Energy Agency says mines were found in "restricted areas", and that any detonation should not affect the plant's nuclear safety and security systems.

title.children: Mines found at Ukraine's Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, UN watchdog says

image.altText: A group of people walk in shallow water in front of large orange floating buoys.

items.synopsis: The newly installed floating barrier on the Rio Grande is the Republican Governor Greg Abbott's latest tactic to try to stop migrants from crossing into the US from Mexico.

title.children: US sues Texas over floating border barriers designed to stop migrants

image.altText: A blonde white woman smiles in the front seat of a small pink convertable, next to a photo of a man in a hat smoking a cigarette

items.synopsis: Independent cinemas in regional Australia say the so-called Barbenheimer weekend led to a fourfold increase in ticket sales, which was much needed after the pandemic changed the way people watched movies.

title.children: Dual release of blockbusters Barbie and Oppenheimer a shot in the arm for independent cinemas

image.altText: Women wearing red soccer jerseys walking onto a green pitch

image.altText: Black and white photo of large crowd of people, many squinting into the sun, aboard a boat, just visible.

items.synopsis: In 1975, Indonesia troops invaded Timor-Leste, targeting, among others, the Chinese Hakka ethnic minority. These people remember what the day was like.

image.altText: The inside of a warehouse showing stacks of soft plastics, with some closer up.

image.altText: Stills of video which played a role in the Australian's four month investigation

image.altText: a man in a simple black jacket sits behind microphones

items.synopsis: China's economy is in serious trouble. The country's property sector, once a powerhouse of national economic growth, is in meltdown — and there are predictions of worse to come, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: China's economy is in serious trouble — and it's bad news for Australia

image.altText: An older man and woman smile in front of a billboard showing a house that had been sold at an auction.

items.synopsis: Higher interest rates and rising house prices have not deterred migrants, retirees and first home buyers relying on "the bank of mum and dad" from buying property, despite data showing a lower number of property settlements.

title.children: The Lindemans bought their new home at auction — and paid in cash. They're part of a growing trend

image.altText: A black and white graphic of a woman in profile, with a brain symbol over her head, with confused lightning shapes to her right.

items.synopsis: Imogen describes life with ADHD as "like running a race and realising you're the only one wearing weights on your ankles". She's sharing her story in the wake of a parliamentary inquiry.

title.children: Months of waiting, excessive costs, inexperienced medical staff — what it's like to get an ADHD diagnosis

image.altText: A black and white image of one man holding another man's hair up.

items.synopsis: Trevor Francis, who made history as England's first player to be paid 1 million pounds, dies of a heart attack in Spain at the age of 69.

title.children: England football mourns the death of history-making star forward

image.altText: A commercial fridge filled with Coca Cola and other soft drinks.

items.synopsis: In April, the nation's doctors called again for the introduction of a tax on sugar-sweetened drinks. They are not alone, but here's an insight into why it's still not happening, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: How the long shadow of drink giants pushes public health into the shade

items.synopsis: If you think your favourite chocolate treat seems a bit more expensive than usual, you are not wrong — and analysts say factors including weather and war will keep pushing the price up.

image.altText: A man inside a man-made hole with stones around pointing at an ancient tomb with yellow sand and dirt around.

title.children: Rare dolphin-adorned sarcophagus among tombs discovered at a Roman-era cemetery

image.altText: A young women in suit with a laptop

items.synopsis: Australia is in dire need of highly skilled researchers in the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) sector, but many report being stranded in their home country, unable to do their work here due to visa delays.

title.children: Australia is desperate for engineers like Sara — but she can't enter the country
